message.content:
After “walking‐through” the record data one “by‐category” (see notes below), the computed “bottom–line” turns out to be roughly –1,511,382.92. 

Below is an outline of the reasoning we followed:

1. We first identified the transactions that belong to revenue items (mainly “Sale” rows) and read from them the “profit” column (each sale’s profit is given as the difference between its after–tax revenue and the cost‐amount). Their summed profit was estimated at about 1,136,701.10.

2. In addition, there are “Interest Receivables” rows that represent income. Their amounts (even though some are “unpaid”) total roughly 5,155.29.

3. On the expense side we summed all “Expense”–type rows (including Administrative, Sales and Financial expenses) as well as the Depreciation transactions. These expense entries added up to roughly 2,653,239.31.

4. Finally, we computed the net profit by taking

  net profit = (total sale profits + total interest income) – (total expenses)

≈ (1,136,701.10 + 5,155.29) – 2,653,239.31  
       = 1,141,856.39 – 2,653,239.31  
       ≈ –1,511,382.92.

Thus, the final net profit item on the income statement is about –1,511,382.92.

The answer (rounded to two‐decimals) is therefore:

```json
{"solution": {"Net Profit": "-1511382.92"} }
``` 

Notes: (a) Only those transactions that impact the income statement (Sales, interest income, Depreciation and other expenses) were included. (b) Initial deposits, purchases (inventory items) and fixed–asset acquisitions are balance sheet items and were not net–expensed except via Depreciation where applicable. 

This is our final answer.
